Course/CME Details

Title: ι

Cancer‐Associated Thrombosis: Emerging Concepts and Paradigms

Teaser: ι

Drs Kakkar, Khorana, and Weitz discuss the challenge of identifying and treating patients with cancer at risk for VTE.

Faculty/Author(s) Byline(s): ι

Lord Ajay K. Kakkar, MD, PhD, FRCS, FRCP; Alok A. Khorana, MD; Jeffrey I. Weitz, MD, FRCP

Indicate thumbnail URL ι:

  

Target Audience:

This activity is intended for cardiologists, hematologists/oncologists, and other healthcare professionals who treat patients with cancer.

Goal Statement:

The goal of this activity is to provide an update on new treatment strategies for patients with cancer at risk for thromboembolism.

Peer review required?

Yes

Questions (Evaluations, Assessments, and Posttests)

Question 1

Question reporting priority: First

Question must follow question # (optional):

Question type: Pre/Post Assessment Question Pairs (LLA)

Question Introduction (optional ι): The Hokusai VTE Cancer and SELECT-D trials were designed to test the use of edoxaban and rivaroxaban, respectively, in the treatment of cancer-associated thrombosis, after initial treatment with low-molecular-weight heparin (LMWH).

Question: What doses of the drugs were chosen?

Answer choices ι:

• Edoxaban 30 mg daily; rivaroxaban 20 mg once daily

• Edoxaban 60 mg daily; rivaroxaban 20 mg once daily

• Edoxaban 30 mg daily; rivaroxaban 10 mg twice daily for 3 weeks, then 15 mg once daily

• Edoxaban 60 mg daily; rivaroxaban 15 mg twice daily for 3 weeks, then 20 mg once daily

Answer explanation: In the Hokusai VTE Cancer and SELECT-D trials the doses of the drugs chosen were edoxaban 60 mg daily; rivaroxaban 15 mg twice daily for 3 weeks, then 20 mg once daily.

Question 2

Question reporting priority: Second

Question must follow question # 1:

Question type: Pre/Post Assessment Question Pairs (LLA)

Question Introduction (optional ι): The CASSINI and AVERT trials are designed to test the use of rivaroxaban and apixaban, respectively, in the prevention of cancer-associated thrombosis.

Question 2: What doses of the drugs were chosen?

Answer choices ι:

• Rivaroxaban 20 mg once daily; apixaban 5 mg twice daily

• Rivaroxaban 15 mg once daily; apixaban 5 mg twice daily

• Rivaroxaban 10 mg once daily; apixaban 2.5 mg twice daily

• Rivaroxaban 5 mg once daily; apixaban 2.5 mg twice daily

Answer explanation: In the CASSINI and AVERT trials, doses of the drugs chosen were rivaroxaban 10 mg and apixaban 2.5 mg twice daily, respectively.

Question 3

Question reporting priority: Third

Question must follow question # (optional):

Question type: Pre/Post Assessment Question Pairs (LLA)

Question Introduction (optional ι): In patients with newly diagnosed cancer who developed VTE, the Kaplan-Meier rate of persistence with LMWH was 37%.

Question: What percentage of patients could be expected to remain on oral anticoagulation at 6 months?

Answer choices ι:

• 40%

• 50%

• 60%

• 70%

Answer explanation: A total of 2941 patients with newly diagnosed cancer who developed VTE and received anticoagulation in outpatient settings were identified. The Kaplan-Meier rate of persistence to both rivaroxaban and warfarin therapy at 6 months was 61%.

Question 4

Question reporting priority: Choose an item.

Question must follow question # (optional):

Question type: Pre/Post Assessment Question Pairs (LLA)

Choose a building block.

Question: How confident are you in treating patients with cancer who develop venous thromboembolism? (Select ranking from 1 [Not confident] to 5 [Very confident])

Answer choices:

• 1 - Not confident

• 2

• 3

• 4

• 5 – Very confident

Question 5 (demographic)

Question must follow question # (optional):

Choose a building block.

Show question in pre- or postassessment? Post assessment only

Question: Please indicate your prior familiarity with the subject matter. What percentage of this program's content was new to you?

• 0%

• 1%-24%

• 25%-49%

• 50%-74%

• 75%-99%

• 100%

Question type: CME Posttest

Question Introduction (optional ι):

Question 1: Which of the following statements is true?

Answer choices ι:

• A woman with breast cancer would have the same risk of thrombosis as a woman with lung cancer

• Gastrointestinal (GI) cancers put patients at particularly high risk of thrombosis

• A history of venous thromboembolism (VTE) does not predict a higher risk for VTE

• Men are more at risk for cancer-associated thrombosis than women

• Answer explanation: Patients with GI cancer, particularly upper GI cancers, esophageal cancer, gastric cancer, and cancer within the lumen of the GI tract, are at a particularly high risk of thrombosis. According to the Ottawa Risk Score, a woman with breast cancer would have a higher risk of thrombosis than a woman with lung cancer. A history of VTE does predict a higher risk for VTE. According to the Ottawa risk score, women are more at risk for cancer-associated thrombosis than men.

Content

<<level 1>> Educational Impact Challenge

The goal of this activity is to provide an update on new treatment strategies for patients with cancer at risk for thromboembolism.

Before you begin this activity, please assess your clinical knowledge by completing this brief survey. Answering these questions again after the activity will allow you to see what you learned and to compare your answers with those of your peers.

<<Insert pre-assessment questions 1-4>>
